answers.answer: Okey dokey. You have a number of complicated problems. Don't be frightened. It is likely that these problems will be self-limiting. Square one is you probably have a viral infection. This often affects the cranial nerves, which in turn affect the eye, and this in turn may cause loss of depth perception. This is a varient of Bell's palsy. It would not necessarily show on an MRI. The drooling is consistent with such a diagnosis. You need a consult with what is called an opthamological neurologist. They will do a good neuro work-up and may suggest use of an eye patch. Vitamin C and anti-inflamatories are often prescribed. Do a "pubmed" search (the government database) for current treatments. You also need a test called an HBa1c. Diabetic patients are especially susceptible to cranial nerve palsy's. I suspect you may have diabetes, or an insulin-utilization syndrome. . The foot cramps are characteristic of either/both calcium and vitamin D3 deficiency.

question: I will sum it up as quick and to the point as I can.  I recently had severe vertigo along with jaw and ear pain.  The neuro stated it was not lock jaw and the ENT said it had nothing to do with my ears.  I still have the jaw and ear pain but now it also hurts behind my eye.  After all of that I lost my depth perception in my left eye and cant drive safely.  This is all on my left side.  I have no heat/cold sensation in my feet and my right foot/leg tingles and has mild spasms and cramping.  At night the top of my feet itch and burn...but no rash.  Inbetween the toes are horrible.  My MRI of the brain came back clear as well as my bloodwork for thyroid, diabetes, vit B, etc.  I feel tired and sm plagued w headaches, no concentration and memory.  To top it off...horrible excessive saliva at times.  Help?  I am in limbo!  What could be causing this?  Thanks for reading.
title: Numbness and loss of depth perception
